item.title: Shinta Cho
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Born in Tokyo in 1927, Cho worked as manga cartoon artist, and in 1960 was awarded an international manga prize by an Italian manga organization. After that he concentrated on picture books, but was active in a number of fields including nursery stories, manga and essays. He created both illustrations and text, and was especially noted for his 'nonsense' picture books, winning numerous prizes in Japan. He passed away in 2005.

item.title: Kaya Doi
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Born in 1969 in Tokyo, Doi graduated with a design degree from the reputable Tokyo Zokei University. Doing both the writing and illustrating for many of her stories, Doi is loved by a large fan base for her characteristic warm touch with coloured pencils and the tenderness with which she depicts her characters. She now lives in Chiba on the outskirts of Tokyo, where she lives a slow life with her family and cats surrounded by nature.

item.title: Taro Gomi
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Born in 1945 in Tokyo. After graduating from design school, Gomi became an industrial designer before turning his hand to children's picture books. His prolific activities now extend to include essay writing, fashion and stationery design, animated cartoons for linguistic education and CD ROM production and he enjoys great popularity among children and adults alike.

item.title: Takaya Hama
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Born 1935. In 1984 he published his first novel, 'Claw of the Sun' which immediately won two major awards. Hama's work combines a deep knowledge and understanding of mythology with sharply perceptive characterization and stirring plotlines.

item.title: Satoshi Kako
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Born in Fukui in 1926. Graduated from the Tokyo University Faculty of Engineering, Department of Applied Chemistry in 1948. He is a Doctor of Engineering as well as a Professional Engineer (chemistry). While working at a private chemical company laboratory, he was also involved in settlement activities and childrens councils. After leaving the company in 1973, he has been working as a picture book author. His works (more than 500 titles) range widely, from story picture books to educational picture books on science. Some of his major works are: the Kako Satoshi Ohanashi-no Hon series, (Kaisei-sha), Daruma-chan series (Fukuonkan Shoten Publishers). He received the Kikuchi Kan Award in 2008 and the Special Achievement Award from the Chemical Society of Japan in 2009.

item.title: Yuichi Kimura
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Born in 1948 in Tokyo. Since graduating from university in Fine Art, he has taught university-level Plastic (formative) Art, been an art lecturer at a community college and worked as a presenter on a children's television programme. He has published over 300 titles to date, in an increasingly diverse range of genres (e.g. writing and illustrating fairytales and picture books and writing dramas and comics) and his work is highly praised all over the world.

item.title: Naomi Kojima
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Born in Tokyo in 1950. Author and illustrator of picture books. Spent part of her childhood in New York and her college years in Memphis, Tennessee, graduating from Rhodes College. After teaching art at an international school in Tokyo, she once again returned to the United States, where she published her first children's books. She now lives in Tokyo, writing and illustrating books for children in English and Japanese.

item.title: Manabu Miyazaki
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Born in 1949, Miyazaki worked in a company before becoming a self taught professional photographer in 1972. His work was a breath of fresh air in the world of wildlife photography, and he has won many awards for his picture books and photography. He is currently active as a 'photographer of news from the natural world'.

item.title: Hiromi Nagakura
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Born in 1952 in Hokkaido. Photographer. After graduating from university, Nagakura worked as a press agency photographer. Since 1980 he has visited and taken photos of the disputed areas in Africa, the Middle East, Mid South America and Southeast Asia. Simultaneously, he has continued to watch Afghanistan. He has received many awards and journalist prizes in Japan.

item.title: Jun Okada
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Born in 1947 in Hyogo. Since graduating from university Okada has taught art at a primary school. Okada's highly original fantasy novels invoke fascinating and original new worlds.

item.title: Komako Sakai
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Born in Hyogo. After graduating from Tokyo National University of Fine Arts and Music, Sakai worked at a kimono textile design company. She is currently one of the most popular illustrator authors in Japan. Her sense of colour and writing touch are highly rated in various media and she is highly respected for her ability to accurately draw little children. Her illustrations are used in a variety of different areas, from corporate advertising and movie billboards to CD jackets and book illustration.

item.title: Nahoko Uehashi
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Born in 1962 in Tokyo, Uehashi completed a PhD in Cultural Anthropology (focusing on Australian Aborigines) and is now a professor. The fantasy novels in Uehashi's 'MORIBITO (Guardian) Series', which draw heavily on her Cultural Anthropology studies, have won many awards in Japan.

item.title: Utako Yamada
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Born in Tokyo in 1963, Yamada opened her own teahouse, called Karel Capek, in 1987. At the same time as selecting and blending tea, planning sweet recipes and designing packages, she has also been active as an illustrator and translator of picture books and has worked on more than 20 titles. She lives in Tokyo with her husband and two sons.

item.title: Masayuki Sebe
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Born in 1953 in Aichi Prefecture. Graduated from Tokyo University of the Arts, majoring in craft. He has a reputation for producing brightly coloured illustrations and ideas with sense of humour. He is especially well-known for his activity books, which include puzzles, mazes, quizzes and counting games.

item.title: Toshio Iwai
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Born in 1962 in Aichi, Iwai is well known as a pioneer of media art. He is active in various kinds of media, such as television, music, video games and so on. He is most well known for the daily children's TV show 'Ugo Ugo Lhuga' (1992-1994), which many Japanese children grew up with in the nineties. Iwai is also famous as a creator of Tenori-on, which is an interactive digital musical instrument. He has two daughters, and has designed hand-made toys to play with them. Although these toys were made just for his daughters, due to popular demand, Iwai eventually published a how-to book. 'A House of 100 Stories' is his first picture book. Iwai wrote it to show his daughter how count to a hundred.

item.title: Iku Dekune
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Born in Tokyo in 1969. In 1992, she graduated from Musashino Art University, majoring in printmaking. Her etchings on Grimm's Fairy Tales were selected in 1998 for the Bologna Children's Book Fair Illustrations. In 1999, her works on Grimm were exhibited in Kassel and at the Museums of the Brothers Grimm in Steinau, Germany. In 2003, the picture-book "The Sea Hare (Parol-sha) " was awarded the Grand-Prix at the Biennial of Illustrations Bratislava. Since 2002 she has lived in Prague.

item.title: Katsumi Komagata
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Born 1953 in Shizuoka Prefecture, Komagata moved to America in 1977 and worked as a graphic designer in the Book Department of CBS in New York. In 1986, he returned to Japan and set up his own company, One Stroke. Most of his books can also be found in art galleries both throughout Japan and overseas. He currently holds workshops around the world, where his wide readership of people from all generations can communicate and share ideas.

item.title: Hiroyuki Arai
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Born in Tokyo 1974. Works as a picture book author, a toy designer, an illustrator. In addition to picture books, he is also active in design for advertising, television production, toys and decorative/interior merchandise. His Open up! Open up! Series is beloved of many children for its bold use of colour and expressive warmth. He has also created original characters that are being developed into branded toys. He lives with his wife and two children in Tokyo.

item.title: Katsumi Yamazaki
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Manga (cartoon) artist. Born in Tokyo in 1954.
Began his career as an illustrator for magazines. In 1986, won the 15th Japan Cartoonists Association Awards with Gyoza Dokuhon (The Meat Dumpling Reader) (Shicho-Sha). He is renowned for his unique technique, which he calls shikokue, where he uses a chisel to carve out shapes on thick paper before adding line and colour. In recent years he has also been active as a picture book author, and is active in exhibiting his works.

item.title: Kanayo Sugiyama
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Born in Shizuoka Prefecture in 1967.
Graduated from Tokyo Gakugei University with a degree in Elementary Art Education. Began work as a designer for a stationary firm. Went freelance in 1990, and learnt etching through The Art Students League of New York. Is currently active as a picture book author. In 1998 she was awarded the Picture Book Award for Pengin no Hon (The Book of Penguins) (Kodansha) won the Kodansha Publication Culture Award for Picture Books. She continues to be active in diverse fields, including stationary design, book covers and illustrations.
She loves dogs, hats and letters. She has a collection of 100 hats in her Tokyo home. She also enjoys collecting stones and nuts fallen from trees. She lives with her daughter, son and husband.

item.title: Akira Fujishima
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Born in Tokyo in 1942. Graduated from the Yokohama National University School of Engineering in 1966. Completed a doctoral course at the Tokyo University Graduate School of Engineering and obtained a Ph.D. in engineering in 1971. He has been the President of Tokyo University of Science since 2010. He received the Asahi Prize in 1983, the Chemical Society of Japan Award in 2000, the Purple Ribbon Medal (Shijuhosho) in 2003, the Japan Prize, the Japan Academy Prize and was named an Honorable Citizen of Kawasaki City in 2004. He also received the Imperial Invention Award and Kanagawa Culture Award in 2006, and Person of Cultural Merit in 2010.
